content: The "Combating Autism Act of 2005" authorizes funding for developmental disabilities surveillance and research programs, including information and education related to autism. The Secretary will establish a program to provide information and education on autism to health professionals and the public, with a focus on early identification and referral for services. Stipends may be provided for health professionals in training programs. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. Stipends may be provided for health professionals in training programs. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. SEC. 399BB. INTERAGENCY AUTISM COORDINATING COMMITTEE. The Secretary will establish the Autism Coordinating Committee to coordinate efforts within the Department of Health and Human Services regarding autism. The Committee will include the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Directors of national research institutes of the National Institutes of Health, and heads of other relevant agencies as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may appoint additional members to the Autism Coordinating Committee, including individuals with autism, parents or guardians of individuals with autism, representatives of autism research organizations, and representatives from other government agencies serving children with autism. Administrative support, terms of service, and other provisions will apply to the Committee. The Committee appointed by the Secretary shall receive necessary administrative support, members serve for 3-year terms and can be reappointed for unlimited terms, and the Committee must meet at least twice a year. SEC. 399CC. SCREENING, DIAGNOSIS, AND TREATMENT OF AUTISM; MEDICAL CARE FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH AUTISM. The Secretary will award grants to develop statewide autism screening, diagnosis, and intervention programs to ensure early detection and appropriate services for children at risk for autism. The Secretary will award grants for statewide autism screening, diagnosis, and intervention programs to provide early services for children with autism. This includes referral to schools, agencies, and organizations offering programs tailored to meet the unique needs of children with autism. Data collection for research and policy development, as well as comprehensive medical care with a focus on associated conditions, are also part of the initiative. A grant will be awarded to a national organization to establish regional centers of clinical excellence for individuals with autism. These centers will provide medical care, promote research, and maintain a national medical database. Parental consent is required for screenings and services for children with autism. The Secretary will set aside funds for activities related to autism from 2007 to 2011. Grants will be awarded for technical assistance, data management, and research on autism screening and intervention programs. Standardized procedures for data management and program effectiveness will be developed. The program aims to ensure quality monitoring, provide technical assistance, study costs and effectiveness, identify causes and risk factors, assess development in children with autism, and promote data sharing. The program aims to promote data sharing on autism with monitoring programs and environmental agencies to identify causes and risk factors. Collaboration with federal, state, and local agencies is essential for effective implementation. The curr_chunk discusses services for individuals with autism, including Medicaid programs, State Children's Health Insurance Program, Maternal and Child Health Block Grant Program, and Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. It also mentions consumer groups, national medical organizations, individuals with autism, and qualified personnel. The curr_chunk discusses the coordination and collaboration of recommendations for policy development at the Federal and State levels regarding autism screening, diagnosis, and intervention programs. It also addresses the need for specialized knowledge and skills to serve autistic children and their families. The Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration and the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will coordinate to assist States in establishing autism screening, diagnosis, and intervention programs. Authorization of appropriations includes $75,000,000 for subsection (a) and $25,000,000 for subsection (b) for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. The Secretary must submit an annual report on autism to Congress, detailing NIH spending on autism research and progress in implementing recommendations from the Autism Research Roadmap.
